Epiphanie is 36 years old and is married with five children between 2 and 16 years old. She takes care of six children. Epiphanie owns a business selling various goods such as cooking oil, rice, sugar, salt, lotions, soap etc. 

This is her 6 successful year in this business and the hours of her work are from 5:30 am until 8:30 pm every day. She currently employs one person to help her.

Epiphanie has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to increase the various goods she sells such as cooking oil, rice, sugar, salt, bread, biscuits, lotions, soap etc. With any profits, she will be able to save for her future, she will reinvest in her business and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, rice, sugar, salt etc to sell.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en: Mila is 42 years old and lives in Ibabao, Siquijor, Siquijor.  She is married with three children. Mila has a general store to earn a living and has had this business for 3 years.  Each month, she earns about PHP 1,000 doing this type of work. She requested a loan to use for capital in her grocery store. She has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for one month.  In the future, Mila hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her general store.

loans.name: María Asunción Del Calvario (Portoviejo) Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Asunción  Del Calvario  se reúne cada quince días en la parroquia Picoaza de la ciudad de Portoviejo. Lugar conocido por ser una zona muy comercial, por sus fiestas tradicionales de San Pedro y San Pablo y por la rica cultura histórica que encierran sus montañas.

Este es un grupo de 10 socias y 1 socio que decidieron unirse y formar este Banco Comunal que les sirve de mucho ya que con los créditos, ellos van mejorar sus pequeños negocios que tienen. Se dedican a diversas actividades tales como comercio, servicios, venta de comidas entre otras actividades.

En este lugar conocimos a la señora Rosa Josefina, tiene 37 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tienen tres hijos de 19, 17 y 12 años de edad el mayor estudia en universidad y los dos menores en  colegio, todos  aun vive con ella. Su esposo es comerciante.

Ella tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa en la cual a pesar de que es pequeña vende de todo un poco, allí sus clientes encuentran desde arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes y muchos productos más, trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, sus hijos le ayudan cuando ella está ocupada, los productos los compra en el centro de Portoviejo aunque la mayoría de sus productos los recibe en su local. Tiene más de 4  años con su negocio, le va bien y espera seguir incrementando su negocio ahora con los créditos.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de priM. necesidad. Es su primer ciclo en el Banco Comunal y espera quedarse por mucho tiempo.

Sus metas son seguir adelante en su negocio y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “María Asunción del Calvario” meets every 15 days in the parish of Picoaza in the city of Portoviejo. This place is known for being a commercial area, celebrating the traditional festivals of St. Peter and St. Paul, and having a rich historical culture influenced by the surrounding mountains.

This group consists of 10 women and 1 man who have decided to join together to form this Communal Bank, which has served them by providing loans. They plan to improve their small businesses. The members engage in different business activities such as retail, services, selling food, and other trades.

In this place, one can meet Sra. Rosa Josefina. She is 37 years old, married, and has three children (ages 19, 17, and 12). Her oldest child is studying at the university and two younger ones are in high school. All of them live with her. Her husband is a merchant.

Rosa has a food store in her home. Even though her business is small, she sells a little bit of everything. Her customers can find rice, sugar, oil, detegerents, and many other products. She works every day from 6am to 8pm, and sometimes much later. Her children help whenever she is busy. Rosa buys her products in central Portoviejo and most of the items are delivered to her store. She has been in business for more than four years. She is doing well and hopes to continue growing her business now that she has access to the loans.

This loan will be used to acquire more inventory for her store. Rosa plans to buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages, and other products that are basic necessities. This is her first loan cycle with the Communal Bank and she hopes to stay with the group for a long time. Her goals are to move forward in her business and to grow her store each day.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages, and other products.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
This is Rosalinda, 40, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Sandy, an employee, and a mother to her three children. She keeps herself busy attending to the needs of her family and business. 

Rosalinda owns a bakery. She sells and offers a variety of breads everyday in her community. She believes that people nowadays prioritize the three basic needs, and bread is not an exemption as a regular meal in the morning and at snack time. Her regular customers are the people in her local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy raw materials and ingredients needed in her bakery.  She wants to have more profit that she will save for their future.

Rosalinda hopes that her business will grow and last longer. She dreams that her children will be able to finish their studies and earn a diploma.  A comfortable and good life is her dream for them to enjoy in old age. She is active in attending the weekly fellowship* meeting as it inspires her to be more submissive to the will of God. 

*All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials and ingredients needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rachael would like to buy different varieties of clothing materials for her tailoring shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Elishipah intends to purchase a pig

loans.name: Ayyub

texts.en:
Huseynov Ayyub Abbas Oglu is a 56-year-old local farmer and he lives in Gazanbatan village of the Saatliu region. He has a family consisting of 3 children, his wife and himself. The illness of one of the children forces him to spend the majority of his income for the son’s rehabilitation. So he wishes to increase his business scale by purchasing more young calves for breeding.

He applied to “Agroinvest” for credit 700 USD to be spent for purchasing 4 young calves and mixed fodder.

loans.use: Purchasing of 4 young calves and mixed fodder.

loans.name: Atalia

texts.pt:
Atalia Chirinzane was born on the 2nd of March, 1959, in Xai Xai in the Gaza province. She attended school only until the 5th grade because her parents lacked the resources to support her studies. At 10 years old, she and her parents moved to Maputo, to where her father's work was transferred. At 19 years old, her father died, and she was left to live with her mother. Life became extremely difficult. At the age of 22, she and her husband moved in together. Since her husband's salary was insufficient, in 1999 she started selling wood. Through a friend, she came to know Hluvuku and asked for a loan of 800 dollars to purchase more wood in order to increase the volume of her sales.

This business has made a positive and visible impact on this family. It has allowed them to rent an apartment and purchase a vehicle, which her husband uses for his taxi service. The community has been impacted also by this business, which supplies quality wood for the production of furniture and construction of houses. In the future, after fortifying her business with the loan, she intends to construct a house for her children.

Translated from Portuguese by Marco Alves, Kiva Volunteer.

Atalia Chirinzane , nascido em 2 de Marco de 1959 em Xai Xai na provincia de Gaza, apenas estudou ate 5ªclasse isto porque os seus pais nao tinham condicoes para suportar os seus estudos . Com 10 anos muda-se com os pais de gaza para Maputo onde o pai fora transferido em missão de servico. Aos 19 anos falece o pai ficando a viver com a Mãe, a vida tornou se muito difícil até que aos 22 anos junta se com seu marido com qual tem três filhos e vivem juntos até agora. Porque os rendimentos do Marido não eram suficientes , em 1999 inicia o negocio de venda de Madeira . Atravez de uma amiga , ficou a saber da existência da Hluvuku tendo solicitado o montante de 20.000,00mt para compra de mais tábuas de madeira aumentando deste modo o volume do seu negocio.

Este negócio, tem impacto positivo e visivel na familia uma vez que na base deste, foi capaz de comprar uma Flat a qual está a arendar, aumentando deste modo a renda familiar , também comprou uma viatura com a qual o marido faz servico de Taxi. Tambem tem impacto na Comunidade pelo facto de fornecer Madeira de qualidade para o fábrico da mobilia e para habitação. Futuramente, uma vez fortificado o seu negocio através do empréstimo, pretende construir mais uma casa para os filhos.

loans.use: To increase stock of wood in her business

loans.name: Michail

texts.en: Michail B. makes a living for himself and his family of three by transporting people around Ukraine from his home base in Ivano-Frankisvk. An energetic, positive fellow, he has been self-employed as a taxi driver for the past five years. He contracts with a radio dispatching company in Ivano-Frankivsk to help ensure that he has a steady supply of customers in need of transportation. Michail’s typical daily income is around 150-180 Ukrainian Hrivna or about $30-$35. Michail has requested a short term loan of $200 to purchase some new tires for his taxi-cab.

loans.use: Purchase tires for car

loans.name: Mina

texts.en:
Mrs. Mina S. is a resident of Dhalko and lives with her husband, son and daughter. Dhalko is one of the popular commercial areas of  the Kathmandu district.
Her husband, Mr. Birandra S., is a plumber. Her son is studying in grade 4 and her daughter is in pre-primary school. Only the income of her husband is not enough to cover household expenses. So, a year ago Mrs. S. opened a grocery shop. Now she seeks a  Rs10,000 (US$175) loan to invest in her shop to buy grocery goods.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita is 20 years old and the mother of one year old child. She has been selling clothing on credit after becoming a member of MBK.  In this business, she can earn US $2 per day. Her husband, B., works at repair shop and earns US $3 per day. She requests a loan to buy more goods to sell. She is willing to repay the loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: to buy more clothing

loans.name: Namataba B Group

texts.en: Jane Francis K. is 42 years old and married with five children. She owns a retail shop where she sells products that the people in her area use in their homes. She and her colleagues have applied for a loan to expand this business.  Jane Francis plans to use the additional profits to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy new products to sell

loans.name: Kavule D Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Aisha N.. She is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal to sell. Aisha is 33 years old and divorced. She has 3 children ranging in age from 11 to 15 and her children go to school. Each week, Aisha makes approximately UGX 50000 (~ $29 USD) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a piece of land.

Aisha has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, in the amount of UGX 200000 (~ $116 USD) to invest in her business and she paid the loan back on time.

Aisha is joined in her small group by Allen N., Harriet N., Nazita N., and Sauda N.. Allen N. sells cold drinks and wants to buy a refrigerator with the loan. Harriet N. sells charcoal and wants a loan to add to her business. Nazita N. operates a canteen and wants to increase her stock of goods. Sauda N. is in the catering business of catering and is requesting a loan to buy more food and kitchen utensils.

loans.use: To add to charcoal business

loans.name: Zarina

texts.en:
Zarina T. is 32 years old. Zarina runs a beauty salon. The salon provides various services, including hair styling, hair cuts, manicures, and the services of a cosmetologist. At the same time, the salon rents out wedding dresses and national dresses for various occasions. The salon is rather successful and generates a stable income for Zarina's family.

Now, Zarina is planning to purchase new wedding and national dresses to rent out. For this purpose, she requests 1,000.00 US Dollars for a term of 12 months. Zarina thanks all for supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: Purchasing wedding and traditional national dresses to rent to clients of her beauty salon

loans.name: Rehema's Cloth Sales Group

texts.en:
Rehema is 39 years old and is married with three children, ages 16, 14 and 11. Rehema is a batik cloth seller, a business she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 5pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more materials for her business. She will share this loan with her sub-group member, Naima , who has business dealing in charcoal sales.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her batik business.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert E. is a single parent with one child. His repair business is doing well, but his equipment is out of date and he would like to replace it.

He is asking for additional capital to buy more equipment for his repair work.

loans.use: To buy more equipment for repair work.

loans.name: Gerarda

texts.es:
Years ago, Gerarda made weird and wonderful earrings which she then sold. Her business ultimately failed, however, which led her to look at other ways to make a living. That's how she came, 10 years ago, to setting up a business making clothing for kids. She has two sewing machines and a "remalladora" (a specialist sewing machine) at her house. She sells the clothes that she makes in a market near her house. She also makes wool hats.

Her husband lives in Cajamarca and he still has a machine for making earrings. Gerarda sends materials for making earrings to him there and he turns them into products that he ultimately sells. Gerarda also goes once a month to Pucalipa where she sells second hand merchandise--cookware, toys, etc.--that she buys in Lima. She's been doing this for 8 years.

The loan that Gerarda has requested will be used to buy materials that her husband needs to make earrings. Gerarda would also like to have a "recubridora" (a specialist sewing machine) to improve her clothes-making business. She'd also like to make improvements to her house.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Hace 16 años, Gerarda fabricaba aretes de fantasía por mayor. Sin embargo, el negocio no fue bien y quebró, por lo que tuvo que evaluar nuevas posibilidades de trabajo. Fue así que Gerarda desde hace 10 años se dedica a la costura de ropa de niños. Ella tiene dos máquinas de coser y una remalladora en su casa. La ropa que fabrica la vende en el mercado que está cerca de su casa. También teje sombreros de lana.

Su esposo vive en Cajamarca y él aún conserva una máquina que suelda aretes, por lo que Gerarda le manda los materiales allá y él se encarga de soldarlos y venderlos. Asimismo, Gerarda viaja una vez al mes a Pucallpa a vender cosas de segunda mano, como ollas, muñecas, etc. que compra en Lima. Desde hace 8 meses se dedica a esta actividad.

Los préstamos que ella ha pedido le han servido para comprar los materiales que su esposo necesita en la elaboración de los aretes. Gerarda quisiera tener una máquina recubridora para perfeccionar sus costuras. También, le gustaría mejorar su casa.

loans.use: Buy materials to make earrings.

loans.name: Nelly Victoria

texts.es:
Nelly belongs to the Valient Women Communal Bank located on Jr La Habana Mz G Lt 6 in the Calleria district of Ucayali. She is 68 years old and the mother of nine. Since her income did not cover her expenses, she invested her first loan from Manuela Ramos in a secondhand clothing business. She gets up at 7am to prepare lunch for her children, and later she sells her clothing until 5pm. With this loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy secondhand clothing for women, men, and children. Despite her age, Nelly continues moving her business forward, struggling tirelessly despite the difficulties. She will not give up and will keep moving ahead with her family. She is very happy for the support from Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer

La señora Nelly pertenece al banco comunal Mujeres Valientes, ubicado en el Jr La Habana Mz G Lt 6, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 68 años y es madre de 9 hijos, pero sus ingresos económicos no le alcanzan para sus gastos, es así que Nelly con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decide invertir en un negocio de venta de ropas usadas. En la actualidad ella cuenta con un negocio de venta de ropas usadas, para lo cual se levanta a las 7 am, para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos, luego se dedica a la venta de sus prendas de vestir hasta las 5 pm. Con este préstamo de S/. 1500 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, compro ropas usadas para damas, caballeros y niños. Nelly a pesar de su edad aun sigue saliendo adelante con su propio trabajo, luchando incansablemente a pesar de las dificultades, ella no se rinde y sigue adelante con su familia, se siente muy feliz por el apoyo que le brinda Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Compra de prendas de vestir de segunda mano.

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba A. sells fish. She is married, but her husband's income as a worker at a beach resort is not sufficient for Araba and her five children. There is a good demand for her fish. She is requesting a loan so she can increase her stock of fish and increase her sales.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business."

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S., 22 years old, is a young man earning around US$1.50 per day raising pigs to sell. He lives in Dan Run Commune in the Siem Reap Province. He lives with his mother, who is a rice farmer. Now Sao lacks money to purchase pig food to fatten his pigs to sell in time to take advantage of the existing high price market. Hence, he would like to request a loan of US$100 to purchase pig food. He hopes the loan will allow him to improve his business, and he thanks Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase pig food

loans.name: Mrs. Chea Hob's Village Loan Group

texts.en:
This Village Bank [solidarity group] consists of 16 people located in Sre S. Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. They plan to use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Chea H. is the village bank president, and is a farmer who owns a plot of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. Her husband, Mr. Kem Phang, is a cow breeder and firewood seller. As the second business is going well, he wants to expand it; so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more firewood to re-sell the customers. Mrs. Chea H. hopes to increase their income and improve their living conditions. She is 36 years old and the mother of three children. Two of them are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study.

Mrs. Leng N. and Mrs. Sam S. did not come to receive their loans, but their husbands did and so are presented in the picture.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Nine members have end-of-term loans, and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK [Kiva’s Field Partner] has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more firewood to re-sell to the customers

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es: Magdalena tiene 32 años, vive en casa de su familia, ya que es soltera y aun no tiene familia. Se dedica al negocio de la venta de golosinas, desde hace 10 años, ya que al no concluir sus estudios secundarios por diversos problemas económicos y familiares tuvo que dedicar íntegramente al comercio. Magdalena está acostumbrada al trabajo sacrificado, es por eso que empieza su jornada desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana, hasta que la venta sea buena, quedándose muchas veces hasta altas horas de la noche, a pesar de estos sacrificios a Magdalena le agrada su trabajo porque le permite mantenerse y distraerse. El motivo del esfuerzo de esta mujer, es tener un mejor futuro, el cual le permita tener una vida sin preocupaciones económicas. Con el dinero que está solicitando, quiere agrandar su pequeño negocio, comprando más golosinas. En un futuro, a Magdalena, le gustaría tener una tienda de venta de golosinas al por mayor.
texts.en:
Magdalena is 32 years old and lives in her family home as she is single and does not yet have her own family. She sells sweets and has been doing this for 10 years as she never finished secondary school because of various economic and family problems which meant that she had to work full time. Magdalena is used to hard work, and this is why she starts working very early in the morning, until she has sold enough, sometimes staying until late at night. Despite these sacrifices Magdalena is very grateful to her job as it allows her to maintain and amuse herself. She works so hard to have a better future without economic worries. With the money that she has asked for, she wants to enlarge her small business, buying more sweets. In the future Magdalena would like to have a shop selling sweets in bulk.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the amount of sweets she sells/Incrementar la cantidad de golosinas que vende.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.es:
El señor Vicente es nacido en la ciudad de Sucre, Bolivia. Actualmente vive en la localidad de La Guardia, en el departamento de Santa Cruz, Bolivia, vive en la casa de sus suegros con su esposa y sus hijos. Se dedica a la albañilería desde hace 5 años, actividad que proporciona el sustento a su familia, es por ello que en esta ocasión el señor vicente, solicita el crédito, que utilizará para la compra de herramientas, que le ayudarán a una mejor y más eficiente realización de su trabajo. Paralelamente podemos indicar que su esposa se dedica a las labores del hogar,sin embargo y gracias a los créditos que ha recibido su esposo, quiere empezar con el negocio de la venta de refrescos en el mercado, de manera ambulante por ello parte del crédito será destinado a la compra de herramientas y un pequeño porcentaje será destinado a la compra de gaseosas; con ello don vicente ayudará también a impulsar el negocio de su señora.
El objetivo que ambos se han trazado, es iniciar un negocio para su esposa, que este ubicado en las cercanías del Mercado, para asó ambos aportar económicamente al desarrollo del hogar y de algún modo tener mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Señor Vicente was born in Sucre, Bolivia. He is currently living in La Guardia, Santa Cruz Department, Bolivia. He lives in the home of his in-laws with his wife and children. He has been engaged in bricklaying for 5 years, providing support for his family.

The loan that Señor Vicente has solicited will be used to purchase tools that will help him increase the efficiency of his bricklaying business. His wife works at home, and with the help of microlending, she would also like to start a business in conjunction with her husband selling soft drinks in the market as a street vendor. Because of this, a small portion of his loan will also be used for the purchase of soft drinks, and this will help to empower his wife.

Their mutual objective is to have a business near the Market in order to improve their life circumstances--they already have part of the capital they need.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Kreger, Kiva Staff

loans.use: To purchase tools and soft drinks for sale

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles D. is 48 years old, married and has two children. For the last 10 years, he has worked as a taxi driver. He picks passengers up at the local lorry station and carries them to nearby towns. However, his business is in crisis because his car has broken down and needs repair. This loan will permit Charles to fix his car, resume his business and make money to support his family and get his children back to school.

Charles is a member of a loan group called Ultimate Trust Group. Members of this group support one when it comes to repaying the loan.

loans.use: To repair his taxi

loans.name: Dao Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đào Thị Cần năm nay 53 tuổi, chồng chị mất sớm hiện tại chị đang sống cùng 1 con trai đã trưởng thành.  Chị Cần tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  1997, hiện chị là chủ cửa hàng chuyên kinh doanh quần áo tại huyện Kim Động tỉnh Hưng Yên. Nhờ có sự hỗ trợ của con trai nên công việc kinh doanh buôn bán của chị rất thuận lợi và cho thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 để đâu tư mua thêm hàng hóa về bán, mở rộng quy mô cửa hàng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dap Thi C. is 53 years old. Her husband passed away early and she is now living with one grown up son. Mrs. C. joined TYM Fund in 1997. Currently, she is the owner of a retail store selling clothes at Kim Dong district, Hung Yen Province. With the help of her son, her business has grown and brings her an income of 2,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 10,000,000 VND to invest in more supplies to expand her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana vive en la calle Illimani  de la zona 21  de Diciembre , ubicada en una zona periférica  de la ciudad de El Alto
 
Ella vive junto a su esposo, Rufino y sus 4 hijos en su casa propia.

Trabaja junto a toda su familia en un pequeño taller de confección de buzos deportivos los cuales los lleva para su posterior venta semanal, a la localidad de Juliaca provincia fronteriza entre  Bolivia y Perú.. 

El crédito lo destinara  para compra de telas  y así incrementar su producción, por lo tanto sus ingresos
 
Es el primer  crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada la califica para otorgarle el préstamo.
texts.en:
Juana lives on Illimani Street, in the neighborhood of "21 de Diciembre", located on the outskirts of the city of El Alto. She lives in her own house with her husband, Rufino, and her 4 children. She works together with her whole family in a small workshop where they make sweat suits for sport teams. They take them to be sold in a store in Juliaca which is located near the boarder of Boliva and Peru. She will use the money from the loan to buy fabric and then she will be able to increase her production and later her income with increase. This is the first loan that she will receive through Impro. Her business has been evaluated by Impro and she has been approved to receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kendra Gaete, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy Fabric To Make Sports Suits

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga es socia del Banco Comunal Tarpuy que significa Siembra en quechua.
Olga es casada, tiene 35 años y 2 hijos, Olga tiene un restaurante llamado El Misquicha que Significa El Riquísimo en quechua, que se ubica en una avenida concurrida, Olga esta culminando sus estudios de Cheff y piensa implementar su negocio con la venta de comida china.
Olga necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, harina, menestras y sal.
Los sueños de Olga son comprar una casa, tener un local propio.
texts.en:
Olga is a member of the Community Bank, "Tarpuy", which means sowing in quechua. Olga is married, is 35 years old and has 2 children. Olga has a restaurant called "El Misquicha", which means "the deliciousness" in quechua. The restaurant is located on a busy avenue. Olga is finishing her culinary studies and is thinking of beginning her business with the sale of chinese food. Olga needs a loan of 3000 soles to invest in the purchase of rice, sugar, oil, flour, vegetable soups, and salt. Olga's dreams are to buy a house and to have her own premises for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Anne Rodriguez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, flour, vegetable soups, and salt.

loans.name: Mwema

texts.en: Mwema H. is a Tanzanian micro entrepreneur. She runs a clothing shop at Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells both used and new clothes. She purchases business items from the wholesale shops in the Kariakoo shopping center and purchases used clothes from the small traders market at Karume. She also retails to customers at Vituka. She needs a loan of Tshs 600,000 to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy more business items for her shop

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina P., 25, is single with no children.  She has little experience in the BBQ & school canteen business. She sells to the general public 5 days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 800 Tala (~333 USD).  SPBD loans are Selina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks

loans.use: Purchase box of mutton flaps, box of drumsticks, bananas, box of sausages

loans.name: Shahpary

texts.en: Shahpary is the daughter of A. R.. She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan,  and she has four children. And she has got a business tailoring and doing embroidery and she wants to make her business bigger. So she requested an individual loan of 42000 Afghani for a term of 18 months. She would like to say that the loan process is the best because it can support those who really need money for business expansion and want to have a good future.

loans.use: for expanding business

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites works as a gasoline retailer in their village. Most of her customers are owners of passenger tricycles. She wants to make her business grow to be able to increase her income. She plans to obtain many customers in order to earn her more profit but she doesn’t have enough capital to expand her business.

For this reason, she is requesting a loan of Php 5,000. The loan proceeds will be used to purchase a larger volume of gasoline to retail and she also plans to expand her current business into a village store to further increase her daily income to attain her goals in life.

Her goal is to send her children to school because they are really willing to study, especially her eldest child who is presently in secondary level. She and her husband are hoping to provide their children with their educational needs. And by working hard, they know that they can achieve all their goals for their children’s welfare.

Marites is a 36-year-old businesswoman who is married to Jimmy L. Sr. They live in Cabaruan, Naguilian, Isabela. They are blessed with four children who are all studying at the moment. The eldest is Jimmy L. Jr., he is 15 years old, Mary Joy is 13 years old, Mary Jane is 11 years old and Jerome, the youngest, is 6 years old.

Marites is glad to have a happy and wonderful family. Their family has a strong faith in God and they always help each other both in times of difficulties and in times of happiness.

loans.use: To purchase more gasoline to sell

loans.name: Progreso Hacia Adelante 2 Group

texts.en:
Damaris is a mother of three small children, ages five, three, and nine months. Damaris will use the loan to purchase clothes, toys, and phone cards to resell from her home, primarily to people in her community. Her dream is to have a big store one day, with a lot of variety. But more than anything she would like to support her three children, send them to school and see them succeed in life.

We have all heard of the saying, "Give a man a fish and he will eat one meal. Teach a man to fish and you will feed him for a lifetime." Well, how about: teach a man to fish and give him the capital to buy proper equipment, and with that you will feed a man, his family, and his community for generations to come. 

Please help Damaris and her group of entrepreneurs. Thank you.

loans.use: Purchase new clothes, toys, and phone cards to resell

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (227080748) is a 55-year-old female living in the town of Gia Lộc.  She is married and has three adult children.  To make a living, L. owns & operates a restaurant.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community.  L. has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 3,200,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, L. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000,000 VND from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.  L. is now requesting a new loan of 9,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase food & drinks for the restaurant.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase food & drinks for the restaurant.

loans.name: Lucita

texts.en:
63-year-old Lucita D. understands the responsibilities of having a family. Although she and her husband were not blessed with a child, she still feels the need to have a stable job and business. Thus, she started a small grocery store with the help of her sister. Presently, the store has a good status, but Lucita won’t settle for the average. She wants to have additional capital to expand her business.

This is the reason why she joined the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI), a growing micro-finance institution in the Philippines known for its client-friendly services. Lucita is currently asking for a loan from CEVI. And as a member, she actively attends their meetings wherein she gets to mingle with her fellow members in sharing some Biblical reflections.

loans.use: goods for the store

loans.name: Ilda Ernesto

texts.pt:
Ilda Ernesto N. nasceu no distrito da Namaacha, tem 39 anos de idade e mãe de 4 filhos com idades compreendidas entre 6 e 14 anos. Estudou ate 4 classe tendo parado quando perdeu seus progenitores e passou a viver sob responsabilidade dos seus familiares que não foram capazes de suportar os encargos escolares (uniforme livros dinheiro de transporte).

Ilda saiu de namaacha com os seus familiares para Boane (km 16 antes da cidade de Maputo) e actualmente trabalha numa empresa de produção de bananas em Boane (que ate exporta para África do sul). O seu trabalho na Bananalandia é de sacha ha mais de 2 anos com um salário mensal de 2.000,00MT.

Para alem do emprego formal, vem fazendo negocio a mais de 5 anos de experiencia. Vende panelas (compra cada a 130,00MT e vende a 230,00MT) e consegue poupar um pouco para momentos difíceis.
 
Ouviu falar da Hluvuku-Adsema através de amigas que foram primeiras a tomar o empréstimo com a hluvuku.
Esta é o seu terceiro credito no valor de 10.000,00MT para compra de panelas e outros produtos para revenda. Os primeiros empréstimos foram de 2.000,00MT e 5.000,00MT, respectivamente para a mesma actividade.
Não tem tido problemas para fazer o seu negocio, mesmo sem empregada, consegue harmonizar bem o tempo.
Espera ver o seu negocio a crescer bem e depois de pagar este empréstimo vai solicitar outros créditos para construir casa com material convencional
texts.en:
Ilda Ernesto N. was born in the Namaacha district. She is 39 years old. She is the mother of 4 children of ages between 6 and 14. She studied until fourth grade and she had to stop because she lost her parents. She had to live under the responsibility of family members who were not able to support her schooling fees (such as books and money for transportation) Ilda left namaacha with her family members to go to Boane (km 16 before the city of Maputo) and she currently works in a Banana production enterprise in Boane (which exports to South Africa). She´s been working in Bananalandia as a weeder for over two years with a monthly salary of 2.000,00MT. Besides formal employment, Ilda has been doing her own business for over 5 years. She sells pots (she buys each of them for 130,00MT and sells them for 230,00MT). This is how she gets to save a bit of money for the difficult times. She heard about Hluvuku-Adsema through some friends who were the first ones to request loans from Hluvuku. This is her third credit of 10.000,00MT to purchase more pots and other products for resale. Her other two credits were of 2.000,00MT and 5.000,00MT, respectively, for the same activity. She has not had a problem doing her business, despite being employed, she manages to harmonize her time very well. She hopes to see her business grow and after repaying this loan she expects to requests other loans to build her home with conventional building materials.

Translated from Portuguese by Yael Schwartzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Resale of domestic articles (pots, pans, etc..)

loans.name: Diezan

texts.en:
Diezan P. has a 1-hectare rice field and 1 carabao, a farm animal used by Filipinos in tilling the rice field. He has two children and his eldest child just turn 5 years old this year. His wife is Annie P. and they have been together since 2003. 

He is asking a loan of Php 15,000 from community economic ventures Inc. He will use the loan to finance her farm like fertilizers and other needs to grow his crop.

He joined CEVi since 2007. He likes CEVI services because it has the lowest interest rate of 2% per month. They also give insurance ocverge aside from the loans that he availed.

loans.use: farm financing

loans.name: Germán

texts.es:
El Sr. German tiene 53 años casado con la Sra. María Eduvigis Lesme de 52 años, el matrimonio tiene tres hijos todos mayores de edad e in dependientes.
El cliente empezó con un pequeño capital en el año 1.994, en la compra venta de maderas aserradas, luego fue ampliando su negocio, actualmente además de compra venta de maderas fabrica y vende muebles con fina terminación, gracias a la buena atención y calidad de sus productos tiene una clientela formada.
El crédito que solicita es para compra de madera materia prima fundamental para su trabajo.
texts.en:
German is 53 years old and married to María Eduvigis Lesme who is 52. Their union has produced three children who are now grown and on their own. The client started out selling cut wood with a small amount of capital he received in the year 1994. He later expanded his business, and now also makes and sells wood furniture with intricate details and finishes. Thanks to the great attention he provides, and the quality of his product, he has a well-established customer base. The loan he is requesting is for the purchase of the raw material, wood, that is fundamental to his business.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood.

loans.name: Delphine Abégnonhou

texts.fr: A. Delphine Abégnonhou est née vers 1965 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Delphine est mariée à KOKOYE Calixte. Delphine est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. Delphine vit avec ses enfants et supporte les charges de la famille. Delphine vend des condiments de sauces (oignon, tomate, piment, poivre, ail, gingembre, sel, cubes, légumes…), de l'huile rouge de palme, de l'huile d'arachide et du poisson fumé. Delphine est dans cette activité depuis trois ans. C’est au marché Ouando de Porto-Novo que Delphine fait ses achats et vend ses produits de façon ambulante  et à son domicile. Delphine est une cliente d’ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Pour mieux développer son activité, Delphine demande de crédit pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
A. Delphine Agbegnonhou is born around 1965 in Porto-Novo, administrative and political capital of the Republic of BENIN. Delphine is married to KOKOYE Calixte. She is the mother of three children, all in school. Delphine lives with her children and takes care of the family expenses. Delphine sells ingredients for sauce ( onions, tomatoes, hot pepper, pepper, garlic, ginger, salt, cubes, vegetables..), palm oil, peanut oil and smoked fish. She's been in this business for three years. She buys in the Ouando market of Porto-Novo and sells her products door-to-door and at her home. Delphine is a customer of ALIDE who repays correctly her loans. In order to grow her business, she is requesting for loan to strengthen her working capital.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sauce ingredients: onion, tomatoe, hot pepper,pepper, garlic, ginger, salt, cubes, vegatables...

loans.name: Burul's Group

texts.en: Burul, the leader of this group, is a very experienced farmer. Her parents-in law used to keep cattle and left the cattle to her and her husband as an inheritance. That’s how Burul appeared to have inherited not only the cattle but also a way of earning a livelihood. Burul and her husband have raised five children. Her three daughters are already married and live separately. One of her sons, married, plays in a team in a traditional game of “pulling a kid”. He also lives apart from his parents. The youngest son is thirty. He does odd jobs at a factory in the capital but still lives with his parents. In spite of her age, 54, Burul eagerly manages her living herself. She sells twenty liters of milk per day and these days she is occupied with harvesting wheat. If her annual income was averaged, her monthly income would constitute $125. Burul has applied for this loan to purchase some sheep to raise and resell. Her dream is to buy accommodation for her eldest son in the capital. Burul has three partners: Cholponbai, Nestana and Begaiym: Cholponbai, 47, is the father of two children. His wife carries goods to Russia. As to Cholponbai, he trades in cattle. His son, 22, is a taxi-driver and his daughter is a high school student. Cholponbai needs a loan to purchase two calves. His dream is to have Mercedes. But first he is going to see his son married. Nestana, 20, is married and her husband works as a social worker. She raises cattle which is quite courageous of her, since she is just twenty. She invested $465 in this business, which is quite a sum for anybody in this area. She needs a loan to purchase a calf to raise and resell and another calf for breeding. Begaiym, 35, is married and has five children. Her husband produces sun-dried bricks, whereas Begaiym sells milk - nine liters per day. She needs a loan to buy a calf. Selling milk brings her $63 a month. She wants to increase her total population of livestock by having one more calf. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase some sheep to raise and sell

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
Mila H. is from the village of Bangko, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 54 years-old and married with eleven adult children. Mila owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling coconut branch wood related products in the local community. Mila has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Mila joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000.00 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand the business. Mila is requesting a fourth loan of 2,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Sarin M. is 37 years old and resides with her husband and three of her children in Batambong province. Three of her children are in school.

Sarin M. makes a living of US$4 of profit every day by selling fish at the market. She is also supported by her husband who works in construction building houses and also grows vegetables. He typically makes US$5 of profit per day.

Sarin M. would like to take out a loan of US$1,000 so that she can purchase more fish to sell at the market and also a motorbike for transportation.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell and to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is 55 years old and married with three children. Her husband is an electrician.

Rita sells groceries and drinks and has been in this business for a long time. With this combined businesses, she is able to provide food on her table to feed her immediate family members.

Rita hopes for a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Divina's Group

texts.en:
Divina D. is from the village of Burgos. She is 23 years old. Divina is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Divina is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Divina owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Divina earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Divina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Divina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Divina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Divina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou S. is from the village of Magcamiguing, Calamba Mis. Occ. She is 43 years old. Marilou is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marilou joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Marilou from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase things for her manicure/pedicure salon

loans.name: Alice's Group

texts.en:
Alice B.'s main source of income comes from selling fruits and vegetables. She is 49 years old, married and has 10 grown-up children. She is from the village of Sta. Maria, Cauayan City, Isabela. Alice has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Alice joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Alice is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used as additional capital for her business. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income.

Alice is the leader of a 10 member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business

loans.name: Samson

texts.en: S. Samson is a businessman of thirty-five years old; he is married with five children, all schooling. He owns a retail shop which he has been operating for over five years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as sugar, soap, flour, rice, bread, drinks, and so forth for sale. He wishes to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, soap, flour, rice, bread, drinks, and so forth

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cooking oil, rice, kerosene, and flour in bulk

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 46 years of age and married with four children between the ages of 6 and 12. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a four-roomed house, where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for the children, medication and feeding the family. 

Margaret has a stall selling second-hand clothes. She buys these second-hand clothes from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala city, and so incurs transport costs to and from buying her wares. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over 20 years. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season (because she works from a muddy place) and the ever increasing price of used clothes. She sells on a retail basis only.

She has been with Kiva's partner MCDT for over 10 years and is servicing her 30th loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start selling on a wholesale basis only. 
.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng H. is a 56-year-old fisher. She has been fishing with her husband along the Tunle Sap River for years. By doing this, the couple earns profit of at least $6 per day which they use to support their family. Leng H. is a good mother who takes care of three children and another is already married and is living independently. In the past, Leng H. has always hired a villager’s boat in order to fish. Right now she wants to reduce the hiring fees by taking out a loan to buy her own boat and other necessary equipment for her fishing operation.

loans.use: To buy a boat.

loans.name: Iyad

texts.en:
Iyad is a young man from Jabalia in Gaza strip. He owns a small shop which is the only one in its area. Iyad is married and a father of 4 children.

Iyad applied for a loan from FATEN to expand his shop and add more goods to it as well as purchasing a refrigerator for the purpose of presenting different types of frozen food he sells.

Iyad has no other source of income and would like to improve the stands in front of his small shop in the picture above to keep supporting his family and cover life expenses.

loans.use: To expand his shop's inventory and buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Agriculture has from time immemorial been the backbone of Uganda’s economy. Different genres of agricultural activities have given many Ugandan families an improved lease of life. This story is connected to one particular individual in Bushenyi district, western Uganda, who goes by the name of T. Jackson.

This 50-year-old married gentleman has subsisted on his banana plantation for the last thirty-eight years. Though adverse weather conditions have constantly affected his gardens, he has managed to consolidate the gains he has made. As a result his family of seven have enjoyed the benefits. Principally, his children all now attend good institutions of higher learning.

Jackson gleefully reveals he makes close to or even more than 250,000 shillings a month from selling bananas. He is very upbeat that with this loan he will be in position to improve on the mulching and gardening aspects of his business.

loans.use: To pay for enhancements to his farm, principally improved mulching methods

loans.name: Hanna

texts.en:
Hanna is married and blessed with three children who are in school. She runs a business selling African attire and curios to earn a living. She has been in this business since the year of 1997. Her customers are both local people and tourists. She also rears dairy cattle to earn extra income. 
 
Hanna is an active member of a Faulu Kenya group who meet on a weekly basis to save their money. She has really benefited from the group: with the loans that the group guaranteed for her, she has been able to pay school fees for her children, built her family a house, and bought dairy cattle. Her wish is to see her children go through college and be professionals. She has requested a loan of 55,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of African attire and curios to sell.

loans.use: To add stock of African attire and curios for sale

loans.name: Leidi Ester

texts.es:
Leidi Ester U. C. vive en el barrio Santuario de la ciudad de Barranquilla, tiene una  hija de 17 años de edad y  se dedica a la confección de ropa femenina, trabaja medio tiempo  como empleada  de  una confección donde le prestan una  maquina plana ,para que trabaje en su propio negocio la otra parte del tiempo. Aun así ella quiere lograr mayor  independencia,  por eso solicita un crédito  por valor de $2.000.000 para comprar la suya propia y mejorar la calidad de la puntada, porque cuando trabaja en su casa lo hace con una de pedal, "la negrita zz". 	
Leidi hace de todo un poco, es decir maneja  la confección  en línea femenina, infantil y masculina, pero también vende mercancías como cobijas, maletines, termos, maquinas de repostería, abanicos y perfumes y así mismo elabora pasteles los fines de semana y en fechas especiales, porque ha hecho muchos cursos de culinaria y repostería. Su esposo es pensionado de la policía y  su hija ya esta tecnificándose en mercadeo y ventas con el SENA y además aprende inglés en una academia; sus principales clientes son su familia, amistades y sobre todos los oficiales de la policía, antiguos compañeros de trabajo de su esposo; aunque ella  tiene mas de 9 años  de tener negocios, desde que hizo los curso y empezó a explotar lo que aprendió, este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y está solicitandole a esta organizaciòn su financiamiento,  por recomendación de muchas personas que han recibido sus beneficios, espera que su crédito le ayude a aumentar su capital y a poder realizar entregas mas oportunas.
Su sueño mas adelante es tener un carro y que su hija llegue a la universidad, vive con su cónyuge en  el Santuario un popular y uno de los mas antiguos barrios de la ciudad de Barranquilla, ahí se siente satisfecha porque  tiene muchos servicios cercanos como el de seguridad policial, de salud y  está ubicada en dirección al Estadio Metropolitano donde comparten el buen futbol los equipos profesionales de Colombia y es la casa del Junior de Barranquilla.
texts.en:
Leidi Ester U. C. lives in the Santuario neighborhood of the city of Barranquilla; she has a 17 year old daughter. Leidi makes women's clothing and works part-time as an employee of a clothing factory where they lend her a sewing machine so she can work on her own business during her free time. Still she would like to become more independent which is why she is seeking a $1025 loan to buy her own machine and improve the quality of the stitching because when she works out of her home, she sews with a foot-pedal machine she calls, "the little black zz." Leidi does a little of everything--she makes clothes for men, women and children but she also sells such items as blankets, backpacks, thermoses, pastry appliances, fans, and perfumes; at the same time she makes pastries on the weekends and on holidays as she has taken a number of cooking and baking classes. Her husband is retired from the police department and her daughter is majoring in marketing and sales in the SENA while learning English in an academy. Leidi's primary customers are her family, her friends and police offers who were old colleagues of her husband. Though she has worked in this business for 9 years ever since she took her classes, this is her first loan through Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo. She was referred by a number of people who benefitted greatly from the foundation; she hopes that the loan will help her to increase her capital and to get better pricing on her shipments. Her dream is to someday have a car and that her daughter studies in the university. She lives with her husband in Santuario, an old and popular neighborhood of Barranquilla; she feels content because she has many services nearby such as the police and health clinics. She lives near the Metropolitan Stadium where the professional Colombian soccer teams play and near the home of Junior de Barranquilla.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a sewing machine and improve the quality of her stitching

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es:
Rosa es casada y tiene 6 hijos, Rosa junto a su familia se dedican a la fabricación de retablos, en donde plasma costumbres de la región, sus productos los venden en un puesto del mercado artesanal y también a intermediarios que exportan sus productos, además vende artesanía, tejidos, actividad que realiza por las tardes y por las mañanas vende abarrotes en general, verduras. Rosa es socia hace 8 años y aprendió a ahorrar. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra de artesanías.  
Los sueños de Rosa son tener capital propio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Rosa is married and has 6 children. She and her family make "retablos" (sophisticated Andean folk art in the form of portable boxes which depict religious, historical, or everyday events that are important to the Indigenous people of the highlands of Peru and Bolivia) depicting regional customs. They sell their products in a booth at the local crafts market and also to middle-men who export their wares. She also sells other handicrafts and woven items in the afternoon; in the morning she sells groceries and vegetables. Rosa has been a member for 8 years and learned how to save. She will use the funds to buy crafts. Rosa dreams with having her own capital and that her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy crafts.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: paying his second trimester fees in his 4th year at university

loans.name: Tiessiri  3 Group

texts.fr:
TIESSIRI 3 est un groupe de femmes mariées du village de NITOLOSSO dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 30 ans, 4 enfants et cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 3 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur troisième prêt de campagne.
KADIA C., la présidente du groupe,  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants, au grand marché de Kimparana. Après l’hivernage, sa récolte  est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Tandis que KADIA C. espère avoir 40.000FCFA de bénéfice, les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Tiessiri 3 is a group of married women from the village of Nitolosso, San prefecture, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 30 and have four children, and they grow peanuts. Looking to make their farming more profitable, the members of the group decided to join the loan institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. After paying off previous loans, they are now asking for their third seasonal loan, Kadia C., the group's president, plans to use her loan to buy as many peanut seeds as she needs, plus small tools and fertilizer. at the big market in Kimparana. . After the rainy season, she warehouses her harvest long enough for its value to increase, before selling it at the big market in Kimparana. and other nearby markets, retail (or often wholesale) for cash to customers who mostly come from big towns. Kadia C. plans on making a 40,000 CFA profit, while the other group members hope to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA each after their produce is sold, to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seeds and tools.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en: Irina, divorced with a two-year-old son, has been selling women's clothing at one of the markets in Melitopol, Ukraine for the past six years. Assisted by her parents who provided her with some initial working capital, over time Irina has developed her business and gained loyal customers. Today, she has 20,000 UAH in inventory, and her monthly net profit is about 4,500 UAH.  Irina would now like to borrow 9,000 UAH to increase the range of her inventory, hoping to make additional profit and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a 30-year-old single lady with two children: Tiffany Mwihaki, 5, and Jerome Katuse, 3, who are both in school.  She grows and sells vegetables to earn income for supporting the family.  She mainly supplies carrots, vegetables, potatoes, tomatoes and fruits.  She has been in this business for two years.    

She was previously employed and decided to go into business so as to earn enough income to support her family.  Since she joined Pambazuko group in Faulu Kenya, she has acquired business skills.  This is because the group members share business ideas during their group meetings.  Besides, the members of the group also guarantee each others' loans.  

She has requested a loan of 20,000 KES which she will use to expand her business.  She hopes to buy a car for transporting fruits and vegetables.  She describes herself as a hardworking lady.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Thirty-eight year old Mary wants a loan to clear land for planting water melons and for paying labor. She has a banana plantation from which she earns income.

Mary is a married lady with four children. She lives in a permanent house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. She  dreams of having an educated family, several sources of income, and having a plantation of eucalyptus trees for additional income generation.

loans.use: To clear land for planting water melons and for paying labor

loans.name: Kossivi

texts.fr: A. kossivi a une moto qu'il exploite comme un taxi moto, ayant remarqué la rentabilité de ce type d'activité , il souhaite acheter une moto de plus pour accroître ses revenus raison pour laquelle il sollicite de WAGES un second crédit. il a déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qu'il a bien remboursé. il est marié et père de 4 enfants.
texts.en:
Kossivi A. has a motorcycle that he uses as a taxi, having noticed the profitability of such a service. He would like to buy another motorcycle so he can increase his profits. This is why he's requesting his second loan through WAGES. He has already obtained one previous loan through WAGES which he repaid in full. He is married and has 4 children.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of motorcycle

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch S., 45, is married, has three children and lives in Kampong Chnang province. She makes a living selling desserts, usually taking in about $3 a day. Her husband, who we see pictured here, works as a journalist and makes about $1.50 each day. Touch S. is applying for a loan for $700 to buy a motorbike which two of her children need to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Aijan's Group

texts.en:
Aijan T. is the leader of this group. She is 42 and married. She has a son and three daughters. All the children are students.  Aijan works as a librarian at a school and her husband is a taxi-driver. Eight years ago, with the initial investment of 20,000 soms, Aijan started to sell convenience goods at the market.  She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to pay for her son’s education at university.  

Toktogul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 43 and married. She has two sons and two daughters. The first son works as a driver, the second is handicapped, and the daughters study at school. In order to make money, Toktogul sells fish and her husband works as a driver.  Selling the fish, Toktogul makes 15,000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan she wants to purchase more fish in order to increase the turnover of her business. 

Naryngul J., 57, is married.  Her husband is handicapped. She applied for the loan because she needs money to hire labor and start repairing her house. 

Satkyngul A., 42, is married. She has two sons and two daughters.  Her husband works as a welder. She applied for the loan in order to purchase building materials to start repairing her house. 

Sonunbubu A., 58, is married. Her husband works a private driver. Sonunbubu hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to pay for her grandson’s treatment (after a road accident). 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to pay for her son's education at university

loans.name: Marcos Roberto

texts.es:
Marcos es un hombre dedicado al trabajo, casado, muy esforzado por el bienestar de su familia.
Su trabajo es de cadete. Donde cada día brinda su servicio, lleva varios años, siendo de unidad propia. El cual compro con su liquidación anterior de su trabajo.
Las mejoras de su vivienda la ha venido logrado atreves de los financiamiento de Afodenic, en donde con el crédito anterior logro levantar la pared de concreto de enfrente y cerrar bien como porche y puerta de metal. Ahora quiere poner piso ya que es de tierra y desea hacer esta mejora para estar cómodo con su familia y lograr mejor higiene.
texts.en:
Marcos is a married man who is dedicated to his work. He fights for the well-being of his family. Marcos works as a taxi driver and provides his services every day. He has been in this position for several years and operates his own vehicle which he bought using the severance pay from his previous job.

The improvements to his home have been achieved with the help of financing from AFODENIC. His previous loan was used to build a concrete wall at the front of his house, enclose a porch, and install a metal door. Marcos now wants to lay down a floor over the dirt, which will make his family more comfortable and provide healthier living conditions.

loans.use: Purchase materials to lay down a floor in his house

loans.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima B. is the leader of this group. She is 44, married. Together with her husband, who has a profession as a Russian language teacher, she is bringing up two children; both of them are school pupils. Fatima works as a head of studies in the local school. Concurrently the family earns additional income from cattle breeding, which helps to satisfy their daily requirements. The loan purpose is to purchase two calves in order to increase their herd.

Fatima’s partners:

Jyrgal A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 38, married. Her family has a son. The main family income derives from cattle breeding; besides that, Jyrgal works as a school teacher. The loan purpose is to purchase 2 calves to expand their herd. 

Gulmira S., 38, is married. Together with her husband, she is raising three children. The family is engaged in trading, they own a foodstuffs shop. The loan purpose is to purchase drinks, cigarettes, and macaroni to expand their assortment of goods. 

Gulkayir D., 41, is married. Her husband earns money by working as a taxi-driver; the couple is raising two children. Besides that, the family gets income out of clothes selling. The loan purpose is to purchase more clothes for further resale. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase two calves

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “LOS LIDERES”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Gloria; tiene 30 años de edad, y es soltera y tiene 1 hijo; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de un hotel que atiende en la ciudad de Puerto Maldonado, ella quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio. La  socia solicita el préstamo para comprar unos artefactos para su casa.

 La socia agradece el préstamo solicitado  y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the Los Lideres (The Leaders) communal bank, which is located in the district of Huanchac part of the Cusco province and Cusco department.

The member is Mrs. Gloria, she is 30 years old, is single and has a son. The member alternates her day-to-day activities with business of a hotel that she takes care of in the city of Puerto Maldonado, she wishes to enlarge and improve her business. The member needs the loan to buy some appliances for her home.

Mrs. Gloria is thankful and values the loan given to her through this medium and is committed to meet the payment quotas in the time agreed.

loans.use: The member needs the loan to buy some appliances for her home.

loans.name: Arnaldo

texts.es:
Arnaldo es  de la ciudad de Pilar, tiene 23 años y  está cursando el 1° año de la carrera de Ingeneria Comercial en la Universidad de San Lorenzo (UNISAL) de la ciudad de Pilar.
 Sus padres son del interior y se dedican a la agricultura y ganaderia,
Arnaldo se encuentra trabajando como administrador de una Veterinaria de la ciudad de Pilar.
Gracias a este trabajo el mismo se puede mantener y estudiar a la vez, está en los primeros años de la carrera y tiene muchos deseos de concluir. La finalidad de el mismo es el de poder contar el día de mañana de un excelente ingreso como para poder ayudar al progreso de su familia ya que son gentes de una zona muy humilde comento Arnaldo. Actualmente es soltero y vive en una casa que alquila, pero piensa en el día de mañana poder contar con su propia casa tener una familia y poder brindarle todas las comodidades.
El solicita el préstamo para el pago de la mensualidad de su facultad y también para la compra de libros que está necesitando para estudiar.
 Arnaldo agradece este préstamo ya que le ayudará en su estudio y al mismo tiempo podrá contar con referencias crediticias que en el futuro será  de mucha importancia para concretar sus proyectos.
texts.en:
Arnaldo is from the city of Pilar.  He is 23 years old and is in the first year of a Commercial Engineering degree at the University of San Lorenzo (UNISAL) in the city of Pilar.

His parents are from the provinces and they farm and raise livestock.

Arnaldo is working as the manager of a veterinary practice in the city of Pilar.  Thanks to this work, he can support himself and study at the same time.  He is in the first year of his course and he has many wishes to fulfil.  His aim is to be able to have an excellent income in the future so that he can help his family to make progress since he says that they are people from a very humble area.  Arnaldo is currently single and lives in a rental house but he is thinking of being able to have his own house, being able to have a family and being able to provide his family with all the comforts of life.

Arnaldo is requesting this loan so that he can pay his monthly fees to his faculty and also so that he can buy some books that he needs for his studies.

Arnaldo is grateful for this loan since it will help him with his studies and at the same time it will provide him with a credit record which will be very important for him in the future so that he can see his projects realized.

loans.use: To pay his monthly fees and his examination fees

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
